item.title: South Korea’s Top Court Upholds Life Term for Captain in Ferry Sinking
item.description: The court said that “if there had been a timely order to evacuate the passengers, a considerable number of victims would have escaped and lived.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pictures of victims of the ferry that sank off South Korea in the city of Ansan in April, honoring the first anniversary of the disaster.

item.title: Leaked Emirati Emails Could Threaten Peace Talks in Libya
item.description: The United Arab Emirates violated an arms embargo by shipping weapons to one side of the Libyan conflict while offering a job to a U.N. diplomat drafting a peace accord, emails show.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Libyans demonstrated in Benghazi last month against a peace deal brokered by Bernardino Léon, a United Nations mediator.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Organ Transplants Suffer Amid China’s Transportation Delays
item.description: Unlike many developed nations, the country does not have dedicated organ transport systems and doctors must rely on commercial means.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Dr. Chen Jingyu, second from left, and other surgeons performing a lung transplant.

item.title: Kurds, Backed by U.S. Air Power, Try to Regain Sinjar From ISIS
item.description: The move also sought to cut a major jihadist supply line between Syria and the Iraqi city of Mosul.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A convoy of pesh merga fighters on Mount Sinjar. The objective of the ground offensive is to cut a major ISIS supply line between Syria and the Iraqi city of Mosul.

item.title: Letter from India: In India, Many Voters May See Corruption as the Lesser Evil
item.description: The victory in Bihar State by opposition parties calling themselves secular was partly a response to the right-wing Hindu character of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party.
item.dc:creator: MANU JOSEPH
item.media:description: The incumbent chief minister of Bihar, Nitish Kumar, center, in Patna, India, on Sunday.

item.title: World Briefing: Northern Ireland: Ex-Soldier Is Released on Bail in Bloody Sunday Investigation
item.description: The former soldier, 66, who was arrested in connection with the 1972 Bloody Sunday massacre has not been charged.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Korean War Memorial Group Finds More Aid in Korea Than in U.S.
item.description: The foundation does not have the money it needs to maintain the memorial on the National Mall, and what it does have came from South Korean corporations.
item.dc:creator: JADA F. SMITH
item.media:description: The Korean War Veterans Memorial Foundation is struggling to set up a maintenance fund for the memorial in Washington.

item.title: World Briefing: Deal Is Set for Satellite Tracking of Jets
item.description: In light of the disappearance of a Malaysia Airlines jetliner last year, the deal allows nations to set aside radio frequencies so that airplanes can be tracked by satellite.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: New Accusations About Sexual Abuse in Central African Republic Prompt Inquiry
item.description: The allegations involved three underage girls, a United Nations official said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Veteran Italian Diplomat at U.N. to Get Top Refugee Post
item.description: Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said he was nominating the candidate, Filippo Grandi, to assume the post starting in 2016.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn Pledges Loyalty to Queen, if Not to Tradition
item.description: Jeremy Corbyn, the new leader of Britain’s opposition party, again risked the wrath of royalists when he swore an oath of loyalty to Queen Elizabeth II, but apparently not on bended knee.
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Israeli Opposition Leader Withholds Judgment on Netanyahu’s U.S. Visit
item.description: Labor Party leader Isaac Herzog said it was unclear whether Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s visit to Washington was a success.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Nephews of Venezuela’s First Lady Face Drug Charges
item.description: The two men, relatives of the wife of President Nicolás Maduro, were arrested in Haiti and turned over to United States officials, a person close to the investigation said.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, front center, with his wife, Cilia Flores, arriving for a meeting of South American and Arab countries on Wednesday in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: André Glucksmann, French Philosopher Who Renounced Marxism, Dies at 78
item.description: After publishing his most influential work, “The Master Thinkers,” Mr. Glucksmann became one of France’s most prominent public intellectuals.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:description: André Glucksmann, left, with Jean-Paul Sartre in Paris. Mr. Glucksmann came to prominence in May 1968, when, as a teacher at the Sorbonne, he publicly cheered on the student revolt there.

item.title: Mexico’s Governing Party Vows to Stop Using Neuromarketing to Study Voters
item.description: The leader of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, says it will stick to campaign tools like polls and political intuition in its future campaigns.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and KEVIN RANDALL

item.title: Serbia to Give $5.4 Million to Bosnian Town, Site of 1995 Massacre
item.description: Characterized as a gesture of good will, the donation was aimed at fostering development in Srebrenica, where 8,000 Muslims were massacred by Bosnian Serb forces.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Spanish Writer Says El País Column Canceled After Comments on Media
item.description: Miguel Ángel Aguilar said his column in El País, Spain’s leading newspaper, was canceled after he was quoted questioning its editorial independence in an article in The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: E.U. Move to Label Israeli Settlement Goods Strains Ties
item.description: Officials insisted the guidelines were not a new policy — merely a clarification of existing rules — but Israel quickly denounced the move as a form of discrimination.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Wine being prepared for export at Shiloh Wineries, based in the West Bank settlement of Shiloh, this month.

item.title: Slovenia Builds Border Fence to Stem Flow of Migrants
item.description: Soldiers rolled out razor wire along the Slovenian side of the River Sotla, which forms part of the 400-mile border with Croatia.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK
item.media:description: Soldiers erected a razor-wire fence on the Croatian border in Gibina, Slovenia, on Wednesday.

item.title: European and African Leaders Near Deal on Returning Migrants
item.description: The draft deal being hashed out at a summit meeting in Malta was partly aimed at sending more African migrants who do not qualify for asylum back to their homelands.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, front left, with European and African leaders at the opening ceremony of a summit meeting on migration in Valletta, Malta.
